message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ultrasonography suggest a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The most appropriate initial step in management of DVT is administration of low molecular weight heparin to prevent more clot formation and reduce the risk of pulmonary embolism. Embolectomy and urokinase may be considered in severe cases, but are not the initial step. Warfarin is not started until the DVT has been treated with heparin for at least 5 days.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and history suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after delivery. The most appropriate initial step in management of DVT is anticoagulation therapy, such as low molecular weight heparin. Embolectomy and urokinase are reserved for severe cases or if anticoagulation therapy is contraindicated. Warfarin is typically started after initial anticoagulation therapy for long-term management of DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including fever, pain in the leg, and the presence of an incompressible popliteal vein indicate deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is treated with anticoagulation therapy such as low molecular weight heparin. Embolectomy and urokinase are more invasive options that may be considered in certain cases, but are not the initial step in management. Warfarin may be used in the long-term management of DVT, but is not appropriate as the initial step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of postpartum deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Low molecular weight heparin is the initial treatment for DVT. Embolectomy and urokinase are not first-line treatments for DVT. Warfarin requires time to achieve its full anticoagulant effect and is not recommended as initial treatment for acute DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, such as fever, leg pain, and edema suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT) which is a common complication in the postpartum period. Low molecular weight heparin is the initial step in management of DVT. Embolectomy is not indicated for initial management, and urokinase and warfarin are not the first-line treatment for DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Low molecular weight heparin is the most appropriate initial step in management for DVT. Embolectomy is typically reserved for massive DVT, and urokinase is used in cases of life- or limb-threatening DVT. Warfarin would not be the initial treatment as it takes time to reach therapeutic levels and is not effective for acute treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and symptoms suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Low molecular weight heparin is the appropriate initial step in management for DVT. Embolectomy is not indicated unless the patient is at risk for pulmonary embolism or has failed anticoagulation therapy. Urokinase and Warfarin are not appropriate initial treatments for DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest deep vein thrombosis, and low molecular weight heparin is the most appropriate initial step in management. Embolectomy and urokinase are more invasive procedures that may be considered if the initial treatment is not effective. Warfarin may be used as secondary prophylaxis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) which is a common complication of pregnancy, especially in patients with risk factors such as smoking and cesarean section. Low molecular weight heparin is the most appropriate initial step in management to prevent further clotting. Embolectomy and urokinase are not necessary for the initial management of DVT. Warfarin is not recommended in the acute phase because of the risk of fetal harm.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) which is a common complication after cesarean section. Low molecular weight heparin is the initial choice for management of DVT in pregnancy as it is safe for both mother and fetus, and has fewer bleeding complications than other anticoagulants. Embolectomy and urokinase may be used in severe cases, while warfarin is contraindicated in pregnancy as it can cross the placental barrier and cause fetal abnormalities.
